cs_descriptions.1: Tetrahydrofolic acid, also known as (6S)-tetrahydrofolate or (6S)-thfa, belongs to the class of organic compounds known as glutamic acid and derivatives. Glutamic acid and derivatives are compounds containing glutamic acid or a derivative thereof resulting from reaction of glutamic acid at the amino group or the carboxy group, or from the replacement of any hydrogen of glycine by a heteroatom. Tetrahydrofolic acid is a folic acid derivative that is produced from dihydrofolic acid after conversion by dihydrofolate reductase. It is vital as a coenzyme in reactions involving transfers of single carbon groups. Tetrahydrofolic acid is used to treat topical sprue and megaloblastic and macrocytic anemias, hematologic complications resulting from a deficiency in folic acid. Tetrahydrofolic acid is a drug which is used for nutritional supplementation, also for treating dietary shortage or imbalance. Tetrahydrofolic acid is the main active metabolite of dietary folate. Tetrahydrofolic acid is a strong basic compound (based on its pKa). Tetrahydrofolic acid may be a unique S. cerevisiae (yeast) metabolite. Within humans, tetrahydrofolic acid participates in a number of enzymatic reactions. In particular, tetrahydrofolic acid can be converted into dihydrofolic acid; which is mediated by the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. In addition, tetrahydrofolic acid and formic acid can be converted into 10-formyltetrahydrofolate; which is catalyzed by the enzyme C-1-tetrahydrofolate synthase, cytoplasmic. In humans, tetrahydrofolic acid is involved in folate metabolism. Tetrahydrofolic acid is transported across cells by receptor-mediated endocytosis where it is needed to maintain normal erythropoiesis, synthesize purine and thymidylate nucleic acids, interconvert amino acids, methylate tRNA, and generate and use formate. Tetrahydrofolic acid has a role in nucleic and amino acid synthesis. It is converted into 5,10-methyleneTetrahydrofolic acid by serine hydroxymethyltransferase. As nucleic and amino acid synthesis is affected by a deficiency of tetrahydrofolate, actively dividing and growing cells tend to be the first affected. It is a soluble coenzyme in many reactions, especially in the metabolism of amino acids and nucleic acids.
cs_descriptions.6: Tetrahydrofolic acid, also known as (6S)-tetrahydrofolate or (6S)-thfa, belongs to the class of organic compounds known as glutamic acid and derivatives. Glutamic acid and derivatives are compounds containing glutamic acid or a derivative thereof resulting from reaction of glutamic acid at the amino group or the carboxy group, or from the replacement of any hydrogen of glycine by a heteroatom. Tetrahydrofolic acid is a strong basic compound (based on its pKa). Tetrahydrofolic acid may be a unique S. cerevisiae (yeast) metabolite. Within , tetrahydrofolic acid participates in a number of enzymatic reactions. In particular, tetrahydrofolic acid can be converted into dihydrofolic acid; which is catalyzed by the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. In addition, tetrahydrofolic acid and formic acid can be converted into 10-formyltetrahydrofolate through its interaction with the enzyme C-1-tetrahydrofolate synthase, cytoplasmic. In , tetrahydrofolic acid is involved in the metabolic pathway called the folate metabolism pathway.

cs_descriptions.12: Tetrahydrofolic acid, also known as (6S)-tetrahydrofolate or (6S)-thfa, belongs to the class of organic compounds known as glutamic acid and derivatives. Glutamic acid and derivatives are compounds containing glutamic acid or a derivative thereof resulting from reaction of glutamic acid at the amino group or the carboxy group, or from the replacement of any hydrogen of glycine by a heteroatom. Tetrahydrofolic acid is a drug which is used for nutritional supplementation, also for treating dietary shortage or imbalance. Tetrahydrofolic acid is a strong basic compound (based on its pKa). Tetrahydrofolic acid may be a unique S. cerevisiae (yeast) metabolite. Within mice, tetrahydrofolic acid participates in a number of enzymatic reactions. In particular, tetrahydrofolic acid can be converted into dihydrofolic acid through its interaction with the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. In addition, tetrahydrofolic acid and formic acid can be converted into 10-formyltetrahydrofolate through its interaction with the enzyme C-1-tetrahydrofolate synthase, cytoplasmic. In mice, tetrahydrofolic acid is involved in the metabolic pathway called the folate malabsorption, hereditary pathway.
cs_descriptions.17: Tetrahydrofolic acid, also known as (6S)-tetrahydrofolate or (6S)-thfa, belongs to the class of organic compounds known as glutamic acid and derivatives. Glutamic acid and derivatives are compounds containing glutamic acid or a derivative thereof resulting from reaction of glutamic acid at the amino group or the carboxy group, or from the replacement of any hydrogen of glycine by a heteroatom. Tetrahydrofolic acid is a drug which is used for nutritional supplementation, also for treating dietary shortage or imbalance. Tetrahydrofolic acid is a strong basic compound (based on its pKa). Tetrahydrofolic acid may be a unique S. cerevisiae (yeast) metabolite. Within rats, tetrahydrofolic acid participates in a number of enzymatic reactions. In particular, tetrahydrofolic acid can be converted into dihydrofolic acid through its interaction with the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. In addition, tetrahydrofolic acid and formic acid can be converted into 10-formyltetrahydrofolate through the action of the enzyme C-1-tetrahydrofolate synthase, cytoplasmic. In rats, tetrahydrofolic acid is involved in the metabolic pathway called the folate malabsorption, hereditary pathway.
cs_descriptions.18: Tetrahydrofolic acid, also known as (6S)-tetrahydrofolate or (6S)-thfa, belongs to the class of organic compounds known as glutamic acid and derivatives. Glutamic acid and derivatives are compounds containing glutamic acid or a derivative thereof resulting from reaction of glutamic acid at the amino group or the carboxy group, or from the replacement of any hydrogen of glycine by a heteroatom. Tetrahydrofolic acid is a strong basic compound (based on its pKa). Tetrahydrofolic acid may be a unique S. cerevisiae (yeast) metabolite. Within yeast, tetrahydrofolic acid participates in a number of enzymatic reactions. In particular, L-serine and tetrahydrofolic acid can be converted into glycine and 5,10-methylene-THF through its interaction with the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase. In addition, L-serine and tetrahydrofolic acid can be converted into glycine and 5,10-methylene-THF; which is catalyzed by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, mitochondrial. In yeast, tetrahydrofolic acid is involved in the metabolic pathway called the glycine metabolism pathway.
cs_descriptions.102: Tetrahydrofolic acid, also known as (6S)-tetrahydrofolate or (6S)-thfa, belongs to the class of organic compounds known as glutamic acid and derivatives. Glutamic acid and derivatives are compounds containing glutamic acid or a derivative thereof resulting from reaction of glutamic acid at the amino group or the carboxy group, or from the replacement of any hydrogen of glycine by a heteroatom. Tetrahydrofolic acid is a strong basic compound (based on its pKa). Tetrahydrofolic acid may be a unique S. cerevisiae (yeast) metabolite.

proteins.name: Aminomethyltransferase, mitochondrial
proteins.specific_function: The glycine cleavage system catalyzes the degradation of glycine.

proteins.name: Methionine synthase
proteins.specific_function: Catalyzes the transfer of a methyl group from methyl-cobalamin to homocysteine, yielding enzyme-bound cob(I)alamin and methionine. Subsequently, remethylates the cofactor using methyltetrahydrofolate (By similarity).

proteins.name: Formimidoyltransferase-cyclodeaminase
proteins.specific_function: Folate-dependent enzyme, that displays both transferase and deaminase activity. Serves to channel one-carbon units from formiminoglutamate to the folate pool.Binds and promotes bundling of vimentin filaments originating from the Golgi.

proteins.name: Bifunctional purine biosynthesis protein PURH
proteins.specific_function: Bifunctional enzyme that catalyzes 2 steps in purine biosynthesis.Promotes insulin receptor/INSR autophosphorylation and is involved in INSR internalization (PubMed:25687571).

proteins.name: Serine hydroxymethyltransferase, mitochondrial
proteins.specific_function: Contributes to the de novo mitochondrial thymidylate biosynthesis pathway. Required to prevent uracil accumulation in mtDNA. Interconversion of serine and glycine. Associates with mitochondrial DNA.

proteins.name: Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase
proteins.specific_function: Catalyzes the conversion of 5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate to 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, a co-substrate for homocysteine remethylation to methionine.

proteins.name: Methionyl-tRNA formyltransferase, mitochondrial
proteins.specific_function: Formylates methionyl-tRNA in mitochondria. A single tRNA(Met) gene gives rise to both an initiator and an elongator species via an unknown mechanism (By similarity).

proteins.name: Canalicular multispecific organic anion transporter 1
proteins.specific_function: Mediates hepatobiliary excretion of numerous organic anions. May function as a cellular cisplatin transporter.

pathways.name: Tetrahydrofolate biosynsis, mediated by ribA and trpF, GTP => THF
Tetrahydrofolate biosynsis, mediated by PTPS, GTP => THF
One Carbon Pool by Folate I

wikipedia_page: Tetrahydrofolic acid, or tetrahydrofolate, is a folic acid derivative.Tetrahydrofolic acid is produced from dihydrofolic acid by dihydrofolate reductase. This reaction is inhibited by methotrexate.It is converted into 5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate by serine hydroxymethyltransferase.Many bacteria use dihydropteroate synthetase to produce dihydropteroate, a molecule without function in humans. This makes it a useful target for sulfonamide antibiotics, which compete with the PABA precursor.Tetrahydrofolic acid is a cofactor in many reactions, especially in the synthesis (or anabolism) of amino acids and nucleic acids. 10-Formyltetrahydrofolate acts as a donor of a group with one carbon atom. Tetrahydrofolate gets this extra carbon atom by sequestering formaldehyde produced in other processes. A shortage in tetrahydrofolic acid (FH4) can cause megaloblastic anemia.Methotrexate acts on dihydrofolate reductase, like pyrimethamine or trimethoprim, as an inhibitor and thus reduces the amount of tetrahydrofolate made. This may result in megaloblastic anemia.Tetrahydrofolic acid is involved in the conversion of formiminoglutamic acid to glutamic acid; this may reduce the amount of histidine available for decarboxylation and protein synthesis, and hence the urinary histamine and formiminoglutamic acid may be decreased.

ontologies.name: Saccharomyces cerevisiae metabolite
ontologies.description: 5,6,7,8-tetrahydrofolic acid has role Saccharomyces cerevisiae metabolite (CHEBI:75772)

alternative_parents.name: Hippuric acids
alternative_parents.description: Compounds containing hippuric acid, which consists of a of a benzoyl group linked to the N-terminal of a glycine.

alternative_parents.name: N-acyl-alpha amino acids
alternative_parents.description: Compounds containing an alpha amino acid which bears an acyl group at its terminal nitrogen atom.

alternative_parents.name: Pterins and derivatives
alternative_parents.description: Polycyclic aromatic compounds containing a pterin moiety, which consist of a pteridine ring bearing a ketone and an amine group to form 2-aminopteridin-4(3H)-one.

alternative_parents.name: Aminobenzamides
alternative_parents.description: Organic compounds containing a benzamide moiety with an amine group attached to the benzene ring.

alternative_parents.name: Aniline and substituted anilines
alternative_parents.description: Organic compounds containing an aminobenzene moiety.

alternative_parents.name: Benzoyl derivatives
alternative_parents.description: Organic compounds containing an acyl moiety of benzoic acid with the formula (C6H5CO-).

alternative_parents.name: Phenylalkylamines
alternative_parents.description: Organic amines where the amine group is secondary and linked on one end to a phenyl group and on the other end, to an alkyl group.

alternative_parents.name: Hydroxypyrimidines
alternative_parents.description: Organic compounds containing a hydroxyl group attached to a pyrimidine ring. Pyrimidine is a 6-membered ring consisting of four carbon atoms and two nitrogen centers at the 1- and 3- ring positions.

alternative_parents.name: Secondary alkylarylamines
alternative_parents.description: Secondary alkylarylamines with the general formula HN(R)R' (R = alkyl, R' = aryl).

alternative_parents.name: Dicarboxylic acids and derivatives
alternative_parents.description: Organic compounds containing exactly two carboxylic acid groups.

alternative_parents.name: Heteroaromatic compounds
alternative_parents.description: Compounds containing an aromatic ring where a carbon atom is linked to an hetero atom.

alternative_parents.name: Secondary carboxylic acid amides
alternative_parents.description: Compounds containing a secondary carboxylic acid amide functional group, with the general structure RC(=O)N(R')H (R,R'=alkyl, aryl).

alternative_parents.name: Amino acids
alternative_parents.description: Organic compounds that contain at least one carboxyl group and one amino group.

alternative_parents.name: Carboxylic acids
alternative_parents.description: Compounds containing a carboxylic acid group with the formula -C(=O)OH.

alternative_parents.name: Azacyclic compounds
alternative_parents.description: Organic compounds containing an heterocycle with at least one nitrogen atom and one carbon atom linked to each other.

alternative_parents.name: Hydrocarbon derivatives
alternative_parents.description: Derivatives of hydrocarbons obtained by substituting one or more carbon atoms by an heteroatom. They contain at least one carbon atom and heteroatom.

alternative_parents.name: Carbonyl compounds
alternative_parents.description: Organic compounds containing a carbonyl group, with the general structure RC(=O)R', where R=organyl, R'=H, N, O, organyl group or halide group.

alternative_parents.name: Organic oxides
alternative_parents.description: Organic compounds containing an oxide group.

alternative_parents.name: Organopnictogen compounds
alternative_parents.description: Compounds containing a bond between carbon a pnictogen atom. Pnictogens are p-block element atoms that are in the group 15 of the periodic table.

intermediate_nodes.name: Amino acids and derivatives
intermediate_nodes.description: Organic compounds containing an amine group, a carboxylic acid group (or a derivative thereof), and a side-chain that is specific to each amino acid.

intermediate_nodes.name: Alpha amino acids and derivatives
intermediate_nodes.description: Amino acids in which the amino group is attached to the carbon atom immediately adjacent to the carboxylate group (alpha carbon), or a derivative thereof.

kingdom.name: Organic compounds
kingdom.description: Compounds that contain at least one carbon atom, excluding isocyanide/cyanide and their non-hydrocarbyl derivatives, thiophosgene, carbon diselenide, carbon monosulfide, carbon disulfide, carbon subsulfide, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, Carbon suboxide, and dicarbon monoxide.

superklass.name: Organic acids and derivatives
superklass.description: Compounds an organic acid or a derivative thereof.

klass.name: Carboxylic acids and derivatives
klass.description: Compounds containing a carboxylic acid group with the formula -C(=O)OH or a derivative thereof.

subklass.name: Amino acids, peptides, and analogues
subklass.description: Organic compounds containing an amino acid or a peptide backbone, or derivatives thereof.

direct_parent.name: Glutamic acid and derivatives
direct_parent.description: Compounds containing glutamic acid or a derivative thereof resulting from reaction of glutamic acid at the amino group or the carboxy group, or from the replacement of any hydrogen of glycine by a heteroatom.

classifications.classyfire_description: belongs to the class of organic compounds known as glutamic acid and derivatives. Glutamic acid and derivatives are compounds containing glutamic acid or a derivative thereof resulting from reaction of glutamic acid at the amino group or the carboxy group, or from the replacement of any hydrogen of glycine by a heteroatom.

descriptions.name: Tetrahydrofolic acid is a folic acid derivative that is produced from dihydrofolic acid after conversion by dihydrofolate reductase. It is converted into 5,10-methyleneTetrahydrofolic acid by serine hydroxymethyltransferase. It is a soluble coenzyme in many reactions, especially in the metabolism of amino acids and nucleic acids.

Tetrahydrofolate (vitamin B9) and its derivatives, commonly termed folates, are essential cofactors that facilitate the transfer of one-carbon units from donor molecules into important biosynthetic pathways leading to methionine, purine, and pyrimidine biosynthesis. Folates also mediate the interconversion of serine and glycine, and play a role in histidine catabolism. [Biocyc PWY-6613]
Tetrahydrofolic acid, or tetrahydrofolate, is a folic acid derivative.

pharmacology_profile.name: Tetrahydrofolic acid is the main active metabolite of dietary folate. It is vital as a coenzyme in reactions involving transfers of single carbon groups. Tetrahydrofolic acid has a role in nucleic and amino acid synthesis. As nucleic and amino acid synthesis is affected by a deficiency of tetrahydrofolate, actively dividing and growing cells tend to be the first affected. Tetrahydrofolic acid is used to treat topical sprue and megaloblastic and macrocytic anemias, hematologic complications resulting from a deficiency in folic acid.
For nutritional supplementation, also for treating dietary shortage or imbalance.

Tetrahydrofolic acid is transported across cells by receptor-mediated endocytosis where it is needed to maintain normal erythropoiesis, synthesize purine and thymidylate nucleic acids, interconvert amino acids, methylate tRNA, and generate and use formate.
